sections.name: Bogey
sections.text: A bogey typically hunts a single creature at a time, usually a small child or elderly person, methodically stalking and tormenting their prey. Often hiding under a bed, amid a dark attic space, or in a closet left slightly ajar, the bogey delights in the slow, methodical cultivation of fear in its victims.

sources.name: Pathfinder #152: Legacy of the Lost God

link.name: Pathfinder #152: Legacy of the Lost God pg. 78
link.alt: Pathfinder #152: Legacy of the Lost God pg. 78

sections.name: Bogeyman
Bogey Origins
sections.text: While bogeymen stem from bugaboos and bugaboos from bogeys, it is unknown where, exactly, bogeys come from. If superstitious storytellers are to be believed, then bogeys arise from the unfortunate victims kidnapped by bogeymen. According to these tales, victims go missing for months or even years before returning as bogeys to the town they once called home.

sources.name: Pathfinder #152: Legacy of the Lost God

link.name: Pathfinder #152: Legacy of the Lost God pg. 78
link.alt: Pathfinder #152: Legacy of the Lost God pg. 78

sections.name: Epidemic of Terror
sections.text: Bogeymen and their lesser kin delight in instilling fear in small communities where gossip can quickly amplify their shadowy deeds. In such locales, bogeymen use peoples’ natural tendency to spread misinformation to sow discord and escape notice—for who would rightfully believe that an actual bogeyman is behind the latest murder?

sources.name: Pathfinder #152: Legacy of the Lost God

link.name: Pathfinder #152: Legacy of the Lost God pg. 78
link.alt: Pathfinder #152: Legacy of the Lost God pg. 78

sections.text: Bogeymen are stealers of innocence and devourers of souls. Few targets who survive an encounter with them remain unchanged. Different names are given to bogeymen according to their varying sizes and degrees of power, which typically advance as the monsters consume more souls.

sources.name: Pathfinder #152: Legacy of the Lost God

link.name: Pathfinder #152: Legacy of the Lost God pg. 78

link.name: Pathfinder #152: Legacy of the Lost God pg. 78
link.alt: Pathfinder #152: Legacy of the Lost God pg. 78

traits.name: Uncommon
traits.text: Something of uncommon rarity requires special training or comes from a particular culture or part of the world. Some character choices give access to uncommon options, and the GM can choose to allow access for anyone. Less is known about uncommon creatures than common creatures. They typically can't be summoned. The DC of Recall Knowledge checks related to these creature is increased by 2.

traits.name: Evil
traits.text: Evil effects often manipulate energy from evil-aligned Outer Planes and are antithetical to good divine servants or divine servants of good deities. A creature with this trait is evil in alignment.

traits.name: Fey
traits.text: Creatures of the First World are called the fey

sources.name: Pathfinder #152: Legacy of the Lost God

link.name: Pathfinder #152: Legacy of the Lost God pg. 78
link.alt: Pathfinder #152: Legacy of the Lost God pg. 78

traits.name: Agile
traits.text: The multiple attack penalty you take with this weapon on the second attack on your turn is –4 instead of –5, and –8 instead of –10 on the third and subsequent attacks in the turn.

traits.name: Finesse
traits.text: You can use your Dexterity modifier instead of your Strength modifier on attack rolls using this melee weapon. You still calculate damage using Strength.

traits.name: Magical
traits.text: Something with the magical trait is imbued with magical energies not tied to a specific tradition of magic. Some items or effects are closely tied to a particular tradition of magic. In these cases, the item has the arcane, divine, occult, or primal trait instead of the magical trait. Any of these traits indicate that the item is magical.

ability.name: Devour Soul

traits.name: Necromancy
traits.text: Effects and magic items with this trait are associated with the necromancy school of magic, typically involving forces of life and death.

traits.name: Occult
traits.text:
This magic comes from the occult tradition, calling upon bizarre and ephemeral mysteries. Anything with this trait is magical.  
  
A creature with this trait is primarily constituted of or has a strong connection to occult magic.

ability.requirement: The bogey has killed a creature within the last round and is adjacent to the creature
ability.effect: The bogey consumes the creature’s soul. The soul is utterly destroyed—nothing short of wish or a similar effect can restore it to life, and only after the bogey has been slain. The bogey regains Hit Points equal to double the level of the consumed creature. After devouring three souls within a year, the bogey transforms into a bugaboo.

ability.name: Surprise Attack
ability.text: On the first round of combat, creatures that haven’t acted yet are flat-footed to the bogey.
